subhead: The French president visited the southern city just over a month after the killing of Mehdi Kessaci, brother of environmental activist Amine Kessaci. Determined to combat drug trafficking, he had to contend with the tumult of looming municipal elections.

Mineral water fraud: Nestlé sued for €1.6 billion over 'unfair competition'
subhead: Le Monde has learned that Nestlé Waters is being sued by its competitor Bonneval Emergence, which is demanding that Perrier, Vittel, Contrex and Hépar waters be withdrawn from the market.

title: EU-Mercosur agreement: Do Brussels' latest measures offer greater protection?
subhead: With a safeguard clause, mirror measures and tighter controls, the European Union has made several proposals since September to address concerns over the free trade deal with Mercosur. But the deal itself remains unchanged and the new provisions have yet to be clearly defined.

title: Louvre workers vote to extend a strike at the world's most visited museum
subhead: Unions say frustration has mounted over staff shortages, aging infrastructure and a planned increase in ticket prices for non-European visitors.

title: Jordan Bardella's repeated U-turns on abortion rights
subhead: While the far-right Rassemblement National party seeks to present itself as progressive in France, it accommodates its most conservative partners in Europe, as shown by its repeated abstentions on key pieces of legislation regarding women's rights.

title: 'It is easier to flatter the people than to serve. Therein lies the last obstacle to an RN victory in 2027'
subhead: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Minnesota's Somali community stands up to Trump: 'We are no less American than other Americans'
subhead: After the revelation of a Covid-19 relief fraud scheme involving nearly 80 individuals of Somali origin, the American president deployed immigration police within the large Somali community in Minnesota, whose members are predominantly US citizens.

title: New York's community kitchens reveal the American cost-of-living crisis
subhead: In the world's largest economy, where prices for consumer goods, including food, have soared since the Covid-19 pandemic, 41 million people rely on government-issued food stamps to have enough to eat every day.
